datafield.subfield: Different vertex parameterizations and propagators for the Δ contribution in π-photoproduction

We evaluate the total cross section for the π-photoproduction process and analyze the behavior of the ${\rm{\Delta }}(1232)$ resonance contribution when the photon energy is increased from threshold up to 0.7 GeV. Within this energy range we compare two different parameterizations for the $\gamma N{\rm{\Delta }}$ vertex: the normal parity and the covariant multipole decomposition ones. For completeness, we also compare different versions for the Δ propagator: the first is the dressed propagator obtained including one-loop self-energy contributions (EXACT), the second is the complex mass scheme which consists in replacing ${{m}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}\to {{m}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}-{\rm{i}}{{\rm{\Gamma }}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}/2$ in the bare propagator, and the third is an intermediate approximation between the two previous ones (EXCMS). We conclude that, in order to extend the present calculation to include more energetic resonances in the future and to obtain non-divergent results for the total cross section we will need to use the MD parametrization and the EXCMS propagator.

(i) The EXACT approximation Reversing the Schwinger-Dyson equation without additional approximations and calculating the one-loop self-energy corrections 'exactly', i.e. without performing any approximation in the one-loop integral describing the propagation of one pion-one nucleon inside the loop (see equation (6) from [, 90: #jpgaa5eecbib90]) the propagator can be written aswhere \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}{X}_{\pm } & \equiv & \displaystyle \frac{2m({J}_{1}+{J}_{3}\pm \sqrt{3}{J}_{7}\mp \sqrt{{p}^{2}}{J}_{4})+2\sqrt{{p}^{2}}(\mp {J}_{3}+\sqrt{{p}^{2}}{J}_{4})+{J}_{1}^{2}}{{(1-{J}_{2})}^{2}},\\ {A}_{\pm } & \equiv & \displaystyle \frac{3({J}_{5}\pm \sqrt{{p}^{2}}{J}_{6})-2({J}_{1}\pm \sqrt{{p}^{2}}{J}_{2})}{1-{J}_{2}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} being p={p}_{{\rm{\Delta }}} and the effective mass is given by \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\tilde{m}\equiv \displaystyle \frac{m+{J}_{1}}{1-{J}_{2}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} with m={m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}} the bare Δ mass. The coefficients Ji are functions of s={p}^{2} and depend on the \pi N{\rm{\Delta }} coupling constant g, and the S=1/2, 3/2 spin projectors {{ \mathcal P }}_{{ij}}^{S} are defined in [, 90: #jpgaa5eecbib90]. Because the Schwinger-Dyson equation has been reversed without additional approximations and the self energy one-loop integral has been calculated exactly in this case, we follow the notation of [, 91: #jpgaa5eecbib91] and refer to this propagator as the 'EXACT' one

\end{equation*} being {{\rm{\Gamma }}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}^{{\rm{CMS}}}=\tfrac{{\tilde{g}}^{2}{m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}}{192\pi }. At the s\approx {m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}^{2} region we obtain the approximated expression \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\tilde{m}\simeq {m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}-{\rm{i}}\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{\Gamma }}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}^{{\rm{CMS}}}}{2},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where now {{\rm{\Gamma }}}^{{\rm{CMS}}} is the fitting parameter in place of {\mathsf{a}}. The equation (, 7: #jpgaa5eeceqn7) together with (, 9: #jpgaa5eeceqn9) are the so-called complex-mass scheme (CMS), which consists in replacing {m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}\to {m}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}-{\rm{i}}{{\rm{\Gamma }}}_{{\rm{\Delta }}}^{{\rm{CMS}}}/2 in the unperturbed propagator, ensuring the gauge invariance of the radiative amplitude. The CMS has been used thoroughly in the literature [, 50: #jpgaa5eecbib50,, 84: #jpgaa5eecbib84,, 93: #jpgaa5eecbib93-, 95: #jpgaa5eecbib95]. In [, 50: #jpgaa5eecbib50] only the 3/2 part of the propagator in equation (, 7: #jpgaa5eeceqn7) is maintained since the 'spin 3/2-gauge invariant' vertex introduced in [, 71: #jpgaa5eecbib71] is adopted. Remembering that this kind of Lagrangian interaction has the consistency problems mentioned previously [, 72: #jpgaa5eecbib72-, 74: #jpgaa5eecbib74], in this case the authors fix the resonance widths phenomenologically and not from a self energy calculation. Also, in [, 93: #jpgaa5eecbib93] the same propagator is adopted on the basis of assuming on shell-subsidiary conditions to avoid the 1/2 contribution together with the conventional couplings. For the width they use a parameterization depending on the considered partial wave. On the other hand, in [, 94: #jpgaa5eecbib94,, 95: #jpgaa5eecbib95] the authors adopt the conventional pion derivative vertices for the \pi N{\rm{\Delta }} vertex but take only the spin-3/2 part of the propagator, not allowing the coupling of this kind of vertex to the spin-1/2 virtual contribution of the propagator

Following [, 91: #jpgaa5eecbib91], an intermediate approximation for the propagator can be adopted. It corresponds to the exact expression (, 4: #jpgaa5eeceqn4) but with the assumption (, 9: #jpgaa5eeceqn9) for the effective mass. This will be called 'EXCMS' dressed propagator

(ii) Covariant multipole decomposition A 'covariant multipole decomposition' (MD) analogous to the Sachs choice [, 101: #jpgaa5eecbib101] of the form  egin{equation*}  egin{align*}  egin{eqnarray}&&{{m{\Gamma }}}_{\mu 
u }^{{m{MD}}}={G}_{M}({k}^{2}){K}_{\mu 
u }^{M}+{G}_{E}({k}^{2}){K}_{\mu 
u }^{E},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

The role of gauge invariance and contact interactions for the spin-3/2 fields has been discussed e.g. in [, 82: #jpgaa5eecbib82,, 83: #jpgaa5eecbib83]. As was shown in [, 73: #jpgaa5eecbib73], when radiative corrections are considered it is not possible to keep the electromagnetic gauge invariance and the spin-3/2 gauge invariance for the strong \pi N{\rm{\Delta }} vertices introduced in [, 82: #jpgaa5eecbib82,, 83: #jpgaa5eecbib83]. Thus, we prefer to adopt the usual lower order pion derivative \pi N{\rm{\Delta }} vertex. Certainly, the calculations done in those references, in spite of the formal problem mentioned above, work well in the resonance region but here we pretend to go to higher energies

In [, 92: #jpgaa5eecbib92] the authors consider additional terms in the self energy, because they calculate the width of the Δ resonance at leading two-loop order in baryon chiral perturbation theory. It is important to point out that it would be difficult to implement these calculations in our context

We mention that they agree with those from Jones and Scadron. Using the Dalitz-Sutherland values given in equations (48) and (50) from [, 99: #jpgaa5eecbib99], {G}_{M}(0)=2.97 and {G}_{E}(0)=0.03, we obtain {G}_{1}^{{\rm{SCADRON}}}(0)=2.68 GeV-1, {G}_{2}^{{\rm{SCADRON}}}(0)=-1.84 GeV-2 or, equivalently {G}_{1}(0)=-5.03 and {G}_{2}(0)=-3.24

Experiments measure the total resonant plus background contribution. Thus, to perform a comparison with experimental data would require us the evaluation of the background graphs shown in figure 1 from [, 53: #jpgaa5eecbib53], which escapes the objectives of the present work
